Watching John Cassavetes film, Opening Night, I was reminded of something that Quentin Tarantino said once in an interview about personal experience in being a creator. He said:
“I don’t think there’s any such thing as this has happened to me; therefore, I should film this. It’s more about what do you get out of living the life that is accessible and available to us? What do we get when we watch certain movies or see certainplays in the theater

A teen-aged girl gets the horse of her dreams and is trained by an ex-Jockey to participate in London's Grand National Steeplechase. In post- colonial 1960s Trinidad, a vicious vendetta between rich white sugar grower and an Indian man turns violent. Hieren Kuah has a hangover – and in the intoxicating heat of Port Natal, there are more matters on his mind than owing $350 to six Indians for goods supplied.

Although there is melodrama at the center or rather at the bottom of this film, the story is told beautifully and subtly and the acting is superb.

For a dystopian piece on 'race relations' and perhaps an even more important statement about those that follow a Christian lifestyle - i urge you to see it.<|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|>
